subject: Law
title: Common Law vs. Civil Law
description: A quick, practical guide to Common Law vs. Civil Law.

hook.text: A judge in England follows past rulings. A judge in France follows a written code. Two systems, one goal: justice.

buildup.text: Common law, born in England, relies on judicial precedent. Civil law, from Roman roots, relies on comprehensive codes.

discovery.text: In common law, judges make law through decisions. In civil law, judges apply statutes written by legislators.

twist.text: Most of the world uses civil law. Common law dominates in the UK, US, Canada, Australia, and former British colonies.

climax.text: In practice, the systems are converging. Civil law countries cite precedent; common law countries rely more on statutes.

punchline.text: Two traditions, one destination. The path to justice depends on where you start.
